learning_outcomes.description: Evaluate rock competence through relevant lab testing and classification systems to inform mining geotechnical designs
Assess slope stability and failure modes by integrating stereographic projection, deterministic and probabilistic approaches using software tools.
Analyse the stress distribution in underground excavations to evaluate the stability and ground support options.
Assess caveability in block cave mining and stability in longwall mining.
Propose a technical management plan to address the core geotechnical risks associated with mining methods

assessments.due_date:
13/03/2026 4:00 pm

The lab prac is scheduled for Week 2.
assessments.task_description:
The prac will be held at lab 50-S107. Instruction on lab access will be provided when issuing the assessment.

The class will be divided into two groups of your choice due to space constraints in the lab. Please enrol in your preferred group as soon as possible. You only need to attend your chosen group.

Attending the lab prac is not compulsory, but strongly encouraged. For those who are unable to attend the practical session, the laboratory data will be made available on Blackboard to analyze and complete their reports. The submission due date will remain the same for everyone unless your extension request is approved by the university.

Other important information includes:

  1. Please read the practical handout prior to your arrival.  
  2. Students must wear safety shoes and long pants.
  3. Gloves and safety glasses will be provided on the day.
  4. It is a condition of entry to practical classes that you have completed the Student Safety Declaration Form provided by a member of the teaching team before the class. When you arrive at the practical venue, it is also compulsory to sign in, and sign out as you leave the laboratory. 

Five types of rock testing will be carried out during the prac, which runs for 2 hours or slightly over.

There will be two separate groups, and you can sign up for your preferred group via Blackboard. Please refer to Blackboard for a detailed marking criteria.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.category: Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Practical/ Demonstration, Project
assessments.task_description:
This is an individual assignment. The class will be split into two groups, which you can enrol via Blackboard.

Field mapping practical will be conducted at the base of the Kangaroo Point cliffs. A map with the exact location and the details of requirements will be uploaded to Blackboard.

Attending the field mapping is not compulsory, but strongly encouraged.

When attending, you are required to wear steel-capped safety boots, long sleeves and long pants. You will not be admitted to the practical class if you fail to wear the prescribed personal protective equipment. 

You are also advised to bring a clipboard, pencils and rubber, sunscreen and a hat.

Please refer to Blackboard for a detailed marking criteria.

For those unable to attend, please try to obtain the data from a classmate or contact Zhongwei for assistance.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.weighting: <dd>10% Five quizzes (2% each) scheduled across five weeks. </dd>
assessments.task_description:
Five individual online quizzes, each worth 2%, will be held in Weeks 3, 4, 7, 8, and 10. Students will have a one-week window to access and complete each quiz via Blackboard Ultra. The relevant quiz links will be released on Blackboard closer to the scheduled dates.

Please refer to Blackboard for detailed marking criteria.

Each quiz consists of approximately five questions and has a time limit of 15 minutes. Students are permitted two attempts for each quiz.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
This individual assessment consists of two integrated components: a technical report and an online oral defence. The report assesses students’ technical understanding of the topics covered in the course, while the oral defence further evaluates the learning outcomes demonstrated in the report. To pass the course, students must pass the oral defence.

Detailed guidelines for both the report and the oral defence will be provided in due course. Please refer to Blackboard for detailed marking criteria.

The final report is due at 4:00 pm on 25 May 2026.

Oral defence will be scheduled during the first week of the examination period across three dates (9:00 am–5:00 pm, 8–10 June 2026). Students will be able to select a time slot that best suits their availability. Each student will be allocated 10 minutes to respond to questions related to their report, and the oral defence will be assessed by at least two markers.

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that assistance from other persons, resources or the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Final report submit via TurnItIn on Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.
